passages.text: It is a "macro" trading marketMacro trading has been leading the way in liquidity. CDS indices, CDS index options and credit ETFs have all benefited notably so far this year despite higher market volatility. However, rather surprisingly, bond market liquidity metrics have also managed to improve, despite rising fragility shocks and large drawdowns in risk assets in the early parts of Q2.

We think that healthy market signs in the bonds space (especially the IG market) reflect lower "risk- free" yields, and thus still- strong demand for credit (particularly short- duration paper). This has absorbed market shocks and ultimately led to a "buy- the- dip" mentality. Traded volumes in euro- credit markets have increased over the past couple of years, while turnover metrics have improved. In addition, average trade sizes headed higher YoY during the second quarter of 2025, across high- grade and high- yield corporate bond markets. We also note that the reach for yield has benefited HY bonds slightly more on the margin, as trends have improved notably QoQ.

Assets under management for FMFs have grown to over \(\) 115bn\$ . As a result, they have been an anchor for credit performance lately, despite market wobbles. The strong technical that FMFs are spearheading currently is like that of the ECB SPP program, which bought bonds and locked them into the ECB balance sheet in perpetuity. With the impact of the CSPP starting to wane as ECB holdings decline, we see the rise of FMFs and their asset- accumulating mechanism as the "new- QE" program now, driven by market participants themselves, rather than central banks.

When market volatility rises, corporate bond market liquidity traditionally comes under pressure. But over the past year portfolio trades (PTs) have been stepping in to soften this market reaction mechanism, as more risk and a higher number of trades coincide in periods of higher market volatility. As portfolio trading has been more a feature of the IG than the HY market, transaction costs have not improved to the same extent for the two, leaving HY bond markets somewhat worse off in relative terms. Another manifestation of the differentiating impact in these two markets has been stronger turnover metrics in the IG vis- a- vis HY space, while average trade size trends in IG credit have been lagging those of the HY market.

Corporate bond market liquidity has been further supported by a strong trading liquidity backdrop across all macro risk pockets. CDS indices, CDS index options and ETF trading liquidity metrics have all improved over the past semester. CDS index volumes are close to 2022 rates- driven sell- off levels, while CDS index options trading metrics are now comparable to those seen during the hedging demand peak of the Covid- 19 crisis.
Credit market liquidity 3

The rise of a new "asset" class 3Navigating an increasingly fragile world 8Bond fragility transforming into CDS market fragility 9Buying bonds for "alpha", using macro products for "beta" 11Trading behaviour changes and impact on the CDS world 12

Who would have thought that despite trade wars and marketeers during late March and early April, spreads would have compressed to less not seen in decades. Therefore, investors seemingly reached for beta in the fixed income world. As a result, "macro" ways to trade credit have been dominating. More than ever before, in 2025, investors are trading credit risk via ETFs, portfolio trades (PTs) and CDS indices.

Volumes in the CDS index and CDS index options space are now just shy of levels seen during monumental market shocks (Covid- 19 and the 2022 rates sell- off). ETF volumes have been rising consistently over the past few years. The story is the same for PTs. In short, market participants are looking to manage credit risk via larger and more diversified trades.

While bond market trading liquidity metrics remain on a strong footing, as both turnover metrics and average trade sizes have improved across the board, transaction costs have continued to lag. In our view, they remain much more punitive for bond investors vis- a- vis macro synthetics market instruments.

The healthy market signs in the bonds space reflect the strong market technical on the back of much lower "risk- free" yields, and thus still- robust demand for credit (particularly short- duration paper, via fixed maturity funds). This has allowed market shocks to be absorbed and ultimately led to a "buy- the- dip" mentality.

Investors should consider employing a combination of physical and synthetic credit exposures, along with macro and micro trading approaches, to navigate in a world of tight valuations and less favourable risk- reward proposition across risk- assets.

Inflows into credit funds have been strengthening for more than 20 months now. This is no surprise to us. We have been flagging for some time that when the abundance of "quality" yield starts to wane, fixed income investors naturally gravitate to these pockets that can provide better yields.

Exhibit 1: Out of "risk-free" and into "risky" assets as yields decline We see the path of "beta" buying in the fixed income space persisting in a world of lower "risk-free" rates for the rest of 2025.
Source: EPFR Global, Bloomberg
Exhibit 2: The strongest inflow trend into short-term funds vs. the belly of the curve in more than a decade, 2014-2025
Source: EPFR Global. 15wk rolling average flows for short-term vs mid-term IG funds. % of AUM BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Thus, amid ECB rate cuts and lower "risk-free" rates, we have seen stronger inflows into high-grade funds vs. "risk-free" proxies like government bond and money market funds. We expect the trend to continue for the rest of the year amid lower depo rates and multi-year-low rates vol levels.

Another phenomenon that has gathered pace over the past two years is the rise of fixed- maturity funds (FMFs). These have been growing in popularity due to their "locked" yield for longer maturities and ultimately their ability to "pull- to- par" instead of being more prone to market volatility. We believe investors may continue to be incentivised to lock in the still relatively high yields on offer from high- quality issuers as depo rates decline. Therefore, we would expect them to continue embracing this part of the IG funds offering.

Assets under management for FMFs have grown over the past few years in excess of \(\) 115bn\$ . As a result, they have been an anchor for credit performance lately, despite market wobbles on the back of trade tariffs. We note that the strong technical that FMFs are spearheading currently is similar to that of the ECB CSPP program, which was buying bonds and locking them in the ECB balance sheet in perpetuity.
Exhibit 3: Fixed-maturity funds gain rapidly in popularity, amid the search to lock in higher yields for longer AUM of IG and HY fixed maturity funds (in \$bn, weekly data), 2017 to date
Source: EPFR Global data. We screen across IG corporate bond funds domiciled in Europe on a weekly basis, and aggregate funds that have a date/maturity mentioned in their name.
Exhibit 4: Significant pick-up in the number of new high-grade fixed maturity funds in comparison to their high-yield counterparts since 2023 # of fixed maturity funds from 2017 to date
Source: EPFR Global data. We screen across IG corporate bond funds domiciled in Europe on a weekly basis, and aggregate funds that have a date/maturity mentioned in their name.

With the impact of the CSPP starting to wane as ECB holdings decline, we see the rise of FMFs and their assets accumulating mechanism as the "new- QE" program now driven by market participants themselves, rather than central banks. We note that while assets under the ECB credit QE buying program decline by around €3.8bn per month, so far this year, FMFs have been accumulating assets at a very comparable pace of \(\) 3.1bn\$ , since the start of the year.
Our key question: What is the impact of FMFs on the credit market in terms of what they buy and when they ramp up their asset accumulation?
Our work suggests that FMFs have been historically adding beta via high- yield funds. When yields have been low and ECB depo rates have fallen deeply into negative territory,

FMFs have been beefing up yields via high-yield exposures. However, in periods of higher "risk-free" yields (like in 2022), FMFs had no reason to add credit risk to reach for extra yield. In the past two years, though, not only has the proportion into high-yield credit allocation increased, but FMFs have been avid buyers of subordinated paper (banks and non-fins too).
Exhibit 5: Fixed maturity funds evolution of holdings over time More reliance to beta when yields are low. Proportion of holdings that are AT1 or Corporate hybrids has increased for newer funds
Source: EPFR Global, We track a large sample of FMFs. Year represents year of opening the funds BoFA GLOBAL RESEARCH

The ultimate result has been a notable yield addition that at current market levels is around 70bp over what the IG euro- denominated corporate bond market would offer. However, more importantly, the yield FMFs can currently offer, and based on our estimates based on the FMFs that have been launched in 2025, is double that of money market funds (3.8% vs. 1.9%, respectively, Exhibit 6).

Credit funds have seen a notable pick- up in inflows vis- à- vis government bonds funds over the past two years almost, on the back of depo rate cuts and lower "risk- free" yields. This has provided a notable tailwind for FMFs that have benefited tremendously since the later part of 2023.
Exhibit 6: As yields decline investors are in search of new ways to lock yields for longer Effective yield for different credit risk pockets (€- bonds only)

Exhibit 7: When yields are at the low-end of the range FMFs are becoming the market anchor as they "buy-the-dip", to lock lower yield, Jan 2023-to date When yields are low, FMFs ramp up and buy to lock higher yields
Source: Bloomberg, EPFR Global

However, on the back of a clear path lower to a low yield environment, and as the market is now starting to be more range bound, investors that want to lock in yields are incentivised to buy the dip and hoover bonds out off the market, when yields increase. So far this year, a FMF "buy-the-dip" mentality in the accumulation of assets has been prevalent. While FMFs and their AUM trends are still negatively correlated to the rates market (lower yields, more buying of assets by FMFs), we have seen that FMFs are also ramping up in periods of short snap- backs higher in yields, as they want to take these "rare" opportunities to launch new offerings and lock in higher yields.
Amid the rapidly rising popularity of fixed- maturity funds, portfolio trades (PTs) have been the key route to accumulate bonds swiftly to build fixed income portfolios.
Exhibit 9: Assets accumulation has been impressive for short-term IG funds vs. government debt and long-term funds Cumulative flows (in % of AUM terms), Jan 24 to date

Our work shows that PTs have been a key liquidity contributor for the bond market in periods of stress. Looking back at the recent market vol shock, more PTs both in terms of net risk transfer but also trade counts have been in synch with market uncertainty.
Exhibit 8: The lower the yield backdrop, the stronger the tendency for FMFs to accumulate more assets, Jan 23 to date ...as credit funds tend to flourish in periods when yields on offer decline
Source: Bloomberg, EPFR Global
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Exhibit 10: PTs are the new "tool" for larger risk transfer for bonds when market volatility increases Despite rising market vol portfolio trading continued uninterrupted
Source: Trace. 5-day averages
This clearly shows that investors look at "macro" ways of trading bonds in periods of stress, to mitigate liquidity challenges.
Exhibit 11: Portfolio trading is rising in popularity since 2023 Average weekly # of trades in the US credit market, per week

Source: Trace. We normalize trading volumes at the 5y tenor weighted maturity profile across 4 duration pockets (1-3.1yr, 3.1-5.5yr, 5.5-11yr, 11+yr). We use 2y, 4.3y, 8.25y & 12.5y respectively. BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Exhibit 12: Portfolio trading is rising in popularity Average weekly trading notional (net risk) in the US credit market, per week

Source: Trace. We normalize trading volumes at the 5y tenor weighted maturity profile across 4 duration pockets (1-3.1yr, 3.1-5.5yr, 5.5-11yr, 11+yr). We use 2yr, 4.3yr, 8.25yr and 12.5yr. BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Overall, we find that PTs are a key avenue to rebalance credit portfolios on a monthly basis. The number of trades increases notably in the last week of a month. Based on the average across data we have from mid- 2023, we find that the last week of a month sees the vast majority of PT trades going through vs other weeks – Exhibits 13 and 14.

Exhibit 13: Last week of the month always the heavier in terms of volumes for PTs on the back of credit portfolios monthly rebalancing # of PT trades in thousands (0 indicates the last week of a calendar month)
Source: Trace. Average weekly figures allocated to each week of the month. Data since May 2023 BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

- Bond turnover metrics have broadly improved across IG and HY credit, though more so in HY turnover metrics as investors have been adding beta. Average trade sizes have also improved across the board in Q2, on a YoY basis.- Bond trading volumes have increased YoY, on the back of stronger market technicals, pick-up in supply and, most importantly, strong buying by FMFs that dominate the front-end of the credit curve.

Exhibit 14: The rise of portfolio trades and the impact on credit trading Average trade sizes trend in IG space has weakened over the past 4y, as PTs have been taking centre stage in how credit investors buy bonds.
Source: Bloomberg: TAGG page. In Euro millions. Average trade size

- The rise of Portfolio Trading (PTs) is evident predominantly in the high-grade rather than the high-yield market. We find turnover metrics trending generally stronger in the high-grade space (vs. HY), while trends in average trade sizes have been less upbeat in the case of IG bonds, when compared to their HY counterparts.

- The PT "infrastructure" has shown resilience, as volumes and risk transferring intensity has not been negatively correlated to market stress (despite higher market vol at the peak of the trade war saga, PTs have been active).
- While transaction costs are still relatively high in bond markets (per unit of market spread), the backdrop is much better in the CDS index space, across IG and HY.

- CDS index volumes and CDS index options trade counts have picked up over the past year, highlighting the need for scalable and cheaper-to-transact instruments. When spreads compress materially, investors are looking to participate in the rally, via assets that can be easily liquidated in case of market wobbles. We note that liquidity metrics for the CDS index options market have been the highest/strongest since levels during the Covid-19 pandemic, while trading volumes in the CDS index market have been the highest since the 2022 rates sell-off.
- CDS index trading volumes have increased slightly in relative terms vs. bond volumes in Q2 2025. Both markets have seen almost equally solid liquidity trends.

- The ETF market continues to grow strongly in the credit space, and volumes have risen sharply over the past year. We also note that the market is less concentrated, as a smaller share of ETFs trading volumes is going through the largest ETFs in the market. Note that ETFs are becoming more prominent in the HY space vis-à-vis the IG market (AUM under ETFs vs total AUM in each market).

- While absolute bid/offer costs across the corporate bond market have come down over the past few years, transaction costs normalised to the underlying market spread level have risen across the euro and particularly the sterling credit trading pocket. This increase has been consistent across the HY space over the past decade.  
- High-yield bonds tend to trade at higher transaction costs vis-à-vis subordinated debt (IG hybrids and AT1s), despite the notable beta compression in the high-yield market. We think the need for "quality" yield and IG-rated fundamental risk has been the driver of the outperformance of subs vs. HY-rated credits. We also note that the AT1 market has recently been outperforming the corporate dubs space in terms of transaction costs compression (mirroring also the real market outperformance).

Fragility has been a key feature of credit market behaviour in recent years. The main cause has been central banks' artificial suppression of volatility, leading to a misallocation of risk capital. While credit markets were strong in 2024 and this year so far, short periods of market stress have emerged. Market moves have brought large intra-day ranges. Fragility shock instances have never been higher.
Exhibit 15: Credit investors have been rushing to "hedge" tail risks in periods of stress Our CDS index options market measure for credit market fragility shows the need for tail convex hedges

Source: BofA Global Research. We measure 5-day moves for the iTraxx Main 3m ATM vol vs. moves over the same 5-day period for the iTraxx Main 3M put-call skew (120-80% of the Fwd). We then calculate the 50 day rolling correlation between these two time series. We only present correlations when 5-day implied vol moves are higher than 5 vol pts and implied vol skews steepen by at least 1vol point over the same period. BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Over the past couple of years, risks have pushed up market volatility. However, this has tended to be followed by strong demand and a "buy- the- dip" mentality. This market sensitivity to shocks that directs investors to buying strong tail hedges supports our thesis that fragility is a structural theme for risk assets that is here to stay.
Credit investors have increasingly used the bond market as a source of "alpha", while resorting to macro products to manage directionality calls/betas.

As a result, the CDS market is becoming the vehicle to de- risk rapidly and reposition in beta terms. For that reason, liquidity trends in the corporate bond market have been more "upbeat" in periods characterised by low market volatility. In periods of market stress, while positioning has become more "sticky" in bond land (thanks to CDS indices being used as "liquidity hedges"), the CDS market has been exposed to more downside (large CDS positioning drawdowns observed, as per exhibit 16).

In a world of growing buy- side assets but lower street liquidity, sharp corrections are more common, especially in periods of market stress and macro uncertainty. Dealer inventories of corporate bonds are clearly down on where they were before the Global Financial Crisis, but banks also appear nimber in managing their mark- to- market risks and overall exposures in their securities portfolios.

As absolute transaction costs in the bond market typically deteriorate significantly during market shocks, investors have resorted to the CDS index and CDS index option markets. As a result, over the past six years, there have been some significant changes in the way credit investors have been using this market, against a more challenging bond market liquidity backdrop vis- à- vis that in synthetics.

Traditionally, the CDS index market has been the instrument of choice to hedge downside risks. However, against a more challenging corporate bond liquidity backdrop over the past few years, and amid the need to add a "liquidity" hedge to their long corporate bond portfolios, credit investors have been using the CDS index market as a vehicle to add longs. Sizeable long risk positions have been added in recent years as they look for ways to improve the liquidity characteristics of their bond portfolios.

Exhibit 16: CDS index and bond market flows trends have become more correlated over the past six yearsBond and CDS market flows are more correlated nowadays vs 2011- 2019 timeframe, as investors have also been using the CDS index market as a liquid long (sell protection) in the market. This has increased CDS positioning "drawdowns" when bond market fragility shocks occur.

Source: EPR Global, DTCC. We present weekly cumulative flows into IG and HY European domiciled funds (Shn) vs. weekly cumulative positioning changes in iTraxx Main, XO and Senior Financials CDS indices across all series. A move higher in positioning for CDS indicates investors (non-dealers) have added risk (solid protection) on net basis across all CDS index series.
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

In Exhibit 16, we compare fund flows data into IG and HY bond funds (combined, Europe- domiciled funds as presented in our Follow the Flow reports, latest report link here) with positioning trends in the CDS index market (we combine positioning in the iTraxx Main, Crossover and Senior Fins CDS indices, across all series).

- Up to six or so years ago, CDS index trading positioning typically exhibited a lower (or even negative) correlation to flows into bond funds (exhibit 16, green box).- However, positioning trends have been almost identical in the two markets since early 2018 – in periods when longs were added in bondland, the same was observed in the synthetics space (exhibit 16, red box).

These CDS- positioning sudden "drawdowns" are much larger nowadays than during the European sovereign crisis of late 2011. Some of these "liquidity" hedges that credit investors have been adding to their portfolios via CDS index longs (sell protection/long risk) have come under pressure when markets have been in stress. This is because when credit investors need to derisk their bond portfolios, they will likely resort first to the CDS index market (either by selling their long risk positions, or simply by adding shorts via the CDS index or the options market).

Such a market reaction typically exposes the long risk positioning, as we have experienced in the past couple of years, but also increases trading volumes significantly in the synthetics space, amid a pronounced need for liquid and scalable credit instruments. We note that positioning in the European CDS space is much more moderate than in the bond market (in relative terms). We think this is due to investors taking some risk off the table in order to minimise the downside risks if the recent rise in risks relating to trade wars and tariffs diminishes.

On the back of such a behavioural shift, we think investors will continue to embrace CDS indices from a liquidity "hedging" point of view, and the CDS index options market as a "convexity" hedge. Hedging demand should keep OTM payer implied vols bid in credit, especially in periods of tight spreads and low implied vols. This will ultimately keep implied volatility skews steep and implied volatility premia relatively supported in the credit space.

A trend has been gathering pace over the past few years: more recently issued corporate bonds tend to exhibit stronger liquidity metrics in the secondary market. As time goes by, older bonds tend to trade less often than newer ones.
Exhibit 17: New deals have lower transaction cost than vintage ones Bid/offer per unit of spread, split based on euro-denominated IG bond's time since issue date
Source: BofA Global Research, Bloomberg. ICE. Using around 3850 Euro-IG bonds from EROO. Average of daily bid/offer costs per unit of spread since the start of 2022

Exhibit 18: New deals trade more often just after the issue date, but trading frequencies tend to decline as time goes by... Average trade size (Euro millions), split based on bond's time since issue date
Source: BofA Global Research; Bloomberg TAGG page, only financial bonds. Based on monthly data since early 2020.

Liquidity metrics typically decline notably for older “vintage” bonds; this is apparent in transaction costs and trading frequency terms. As exhibits 17 and 18 highlight, newly issued bonds trade at tighter bid/offer costs (per unit of spread) and average trade ticket sizes are also larger (trade size divided by trade count).

Amid a more challenging liquidity backdrop in the bond market vs that of the CDS index market in periods of uncertainty, investors have been owning bonds for longer, while hedging short- term market volatility via macro products (mainly CDS indices and CDS index options). This is predominantly because of the notable cost benefit of trading macro instruments vs. single- name ones. Investors have increasingly owned bonds for “alpha” and managed “beta” via the more liquid macro instruments (like CDS indices).
Exhibit 19: Higher reliance on IG/HY markets allocation via ETFs, 2011-2025
Exhibit 20: The credit market has still a lot of room to play catch up... ...on the use of ETFs vs. the levels seen in the equity market
Source: EPFR Global, % of total AUM for Equities and HY in ETFs. (2012 to date). BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Our work shows that there is a notable increase in the AUM share of ETFs vs. the entire credit market. Further, we note that the credit market has been closing the gap on the use of ETFs vs. the levels seen in the equity market. The rise of the ETF corporate bond market has also incentivised dealers to offer mechanisms for credit investors to acquire large baskets of corporate bond portfolios. Portfolio trading has been gathering pace in response to investors' need to be able to add a broader range of bonds to facilitate the creation of ETF in credit. That ultimately allows credit investors to express "macro" views via the bond market and not only via the synthetics one.

The CDS index market has evolved from a traditionally "mark- to- market" hedging instrument into a "liquidity" hedging instrument. Investors have been adding CDS index longs in credit portfolios to benefit from the deeper market liquidity in terms of scalability and lower transaction costs. As a result, net positioning, especially for the high- grade CDS indices has been firmly on the long side.

Positioning drawdowns have also been sizeable during volatility shocks. This is because credit investors derisk their portfolios by cutting CDS index longs, which exhibit much higher scalability (vs. any other credit market instruments) and superior transaction cost profiles. While investors have been using the CDS index market as a vehicle to derisk faster (by cutting longs), they have also been using the CDS index options market to hedge and protect against large drawdowns.

- As more investors are using the CDS index market from the long side (selling protection), the index to intrinsics skew has been in negative territory and trading at lower levels for the past six or so years. As exhibit 21 shows, there is a notable drop in the index skew (index tradable level minus index constituents' intrinsics).

Exhibit 21: As CDS market longs have been increasing, the iTraxx Main index has been trading much tighter to its intrinsics than before Index level minus fair value of the index based on where the underlying constituents trade

Exhibit 22: The Implied vol premium to own downside convexity (via OTM puts) has been much higher than ATM implied vols would justify A notable premium in implied vol terms to buy tail risk hedges has been built over the past five years, and since the Covid-19 2020 sell-off
Source: BofA Global Research. Put skew is the implied vol differential between \(130\%\) of Fwd spread and ATM implied vol at the 3M tenor

either. The need for "cheap" convexity hedges since the Covid- 19 sell- off in early 2020 has kept the put (payer) implied vol skew at relatively steeper levels than justified for the level of implied vols (exhibit 22). We think implied vol skews need to be on the steep side, structurally, to reflect the core need for downside convexity (at a predetermined cost) due to rising fragility. This comes on the back of a more
challenging liquidity backdrop in the bond market – when spreads move wider – and thus increasing reliance on the CDS index market to manage beta.
Exhibit 23: When volatility rises CDS indices become the vehicle to trade

Source: Bloomberg, SDR page. Aggregate market volumes for all series trades across CDX IG, CDX HY, iTraxx Main, Crossover, Senior and Subordinated Financials CDS indices. Volumes naturally increase during the Mar/Sep CDS index roll.
Exhibit 24: CDS index option trading increases notably in periods of high market volatility

Source: Bloomberg SDR page; Number of unique options trades across five CDS indices (iTraxx Main, XO, Senior Fins, CDX IG and CDX HY). Note the analysis is underestimating the overall market trade counts as it is not capturing trades where a non US counterpart is involved.

How to trade creditTo trade credit, investors can either use cash or synthetics in a single- name format or via macro plays. Ultimately, the key pillars of trading credit can be split between corporate bonds and single- name CDS on a name- by- name basis, and ETFs, TRS and CDS indices on the macro side. Exhibit 25 presents the relative volumes traded via CDS indices and CDS single- name referenced contracts, but also via the credit bond market.

Exhibit 25: Pick and choose: bond trading share of total volumes declined the past two quarters Trading volumes per product as a % of total volumes. Splitting the market between CDS indices, single-name CDS and corporate bond volumes
Source: DTCC, Bloomberg. Only European CDS indices and single-name CDS. We filter via the TAGG page: only for Euro and GBP-denominated corporate bonds reported under Mifid
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
As shown in Exhibit 25, we highlight the following:

Based on data since 2018, the largest proportion of volumes has gone through the CDS index market at the expense of single- name CDS and the corporate bond market. This can be attributed primarily to the need to trade more liquid, scalable and "cheaper" (in terms of transaction costs) instruments. This has been a consistent theme for years now, highlighting the importance of the CDS index market for mainstream long- only bond portfolios. Corporate bond volumes (Exhibit 26) - as a percentage of overall credit market trading volumes - improved and actually peaked in Q1 2021, amid strong inflows into credit, but most importantly due to very low market volatility levels. Record- low funding costs along with strong demand for credit generated from the ECB QE, was pivotal. This was in contrast to the trend in Q1 2020, when volumes declined (vs. the CDS index market) because of the unprecedented market shock from Covid- 19. The market sell- off in 2022 on the back of the inflation shock across the globe was more detrimental to the corporate bond market than previous episodes. Liquidity became more challenging, especially in the first three quarters of the year. This was on the back of a much longer- lasting rates market headwind. The need for scalable instruments with lower transaction costs to trade credit pushed investors into the CDS index market at levels never seen before.

Lower market volatility since the later parts of 2022 meant the bond market share increased again, while that of the CDS index declined. However, more instances of market fragility in Q3 2024 and Q1 2025 gave a boost to trading in macro products and CDS indices during those periods.
Overall, in Q1 this year, bond trading's share of overall credit trading volumes declined on the back of the tariff/trade war saga (19% vs. 23% in Q4 last year).
Exhibit 26: Volumes have been strengthening over the past three years In euro billions
Source:Bloomberg:TAGG page.

Exhibit 27: 2025 has seen the highest occurrence of fragility events for the past 15 years, up to \(8\%\) in 2025 vs \(6\%\) and \(3\%\) in the prior 2 years Hedging demand in times of stress has increased notably lately \(8.0\%\) in 2025 from \(6\%\) in 2024 and \(3\%\) in 2023
Source:BofAGlobal Research.Fragility events identified as per exhibit 11.

Amid higher idiosyncratic risk, we have seen a rise in volumes going through the single- name CDS market over the past few quarters. Over the past two years, on average \(4.3\%\) of credit market trading has gone through the single- name CDS market. This compares with \(2.7\%\) (average quarterly share of broader credit market volumes) in 2020- 2022.

Macro headwinds, on the back of trade wars, and higher funding costs support a rising idiosyncratic risk backdrop. The increasing occurrence of single- name distress events has ultimately improved single- name CDS liquidity (relative to recent historical trends) as investors need to hedge against higher default risk. On top of that, clearing for such trades has also improved the liquidity backdrop.

Tighter credit spreads and lower market uncertainty have always been a tailwind for risk assets' liquidity. This has clearly been the case most of the time over the past couple of years. However, we find that portfolio trading is a supporting mechanism for corporate bond market liquidity metrics in periods of higher market uncertainty. Overall, bond market liquidity metrics have broadly improved over the past couple of quarters, as sizeable inflows and tighter spreads have been a tailwind.

Turnover metrics (trading volumes vs. market size) and average trade ticket sizes (trade volumes vs. trade counts) peaked in early 2021 but declined consistently in 2022 and the early parts of 2023. However, trends were generally more supportive for turnover metrics in the later 2023 and since then, as market volatility subsided and inflows into credit have improved notably since November of that year.

While there was a dip lower in liquidity trends for IG and HY bond markets in Q2 2024, the backdrop has been more encouraging since then as inflows into credit funds have accelerated. This has been supportive for turnover metrics, which have improved across the board – Exhibit 28.

Exhibit 28: Turnover in the corp bond market has been picking up steadily over the past two years from lows of \(9\%\) in Q3 23 to highs of \(13\%\) in Q1 this year Ratio of corporate trading volumes vs. size of the euro-denominated IG and HY credit market
Source: Bloomberg. Using the TAGG page: including primary and secondary market trading volumes. ER00 and HEDO indices
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Turnover metrics and average trade sizes improved for IG bond markets in Q1 2025 (YoY). However, the high- yield bond market came under some downward pressure owing to much more muted flows in relative terms.

Taking a step back, we have seen a relative decoupling of the high- grade and the high- yield euro- denominated market in terms of average trade size trajectories over the past couple of years. We reckon the portfolio trading boom, more an IG corporate bond market structure development, justifies smaller trade sizes. Portfolio trades (PTs) could also be the reason that turnover metrics (bonds trading vs. market size) have been weaker in HY bonds vis- à- vis IG bonds in the past couple of years (exhibit 29).

This has been a consistent pattern: Q1 exhibits the strongest turnover metrics, while a smaller proportion of the market trades every quarter thereafter. Typically, Q3 has the worst liquidity metrics due to the summer lull (see Exhibit 33).

ER00 and HEO0 bond indices and quarterly volumes that do not exceed the amount issued under that bond ISIN. We exclude trading volumes data for newly issued bonds (issue date needs to be at least 2 quarters away [183 days] from the end of the quarter the ISIN features in the quarterly data set for its trading volumes to be included in our analysis, though these are included in Exhibit 28). We also exclude any quarterly data for a bond the last year before it is called, or the maturity date or the next call date (a minimum of five quarters [458 days] to the end of the quarter so that quarterly data are included in our analysis). We do that in order to exclude data related to trading out of bonds due to benchmarking rules (bonds drop one year before maturity/call date). We apply these filters in order to capture only the core secondary trading activity, with no outliers or any primary issuance-related data. We allocate bonds to high-grade or high-yield based on their credit ratings on issue-date.

While corporate bond market turnover metrics have been more challenged over the past four years and from the peak of early 2021, we have seen an uptrend recently - and since the later part of 2023. This has been mirrored in the average trade size, with metrics heading higher every quarter over the past year (YoY).

We think lower rates market uncertainty on the back of a dovish ECB, along with lower "risk- free" yields, but most importantly the strong inflows into credit funds, have incentivised investors to transact more in corporate bonds. This trend should persist if ECB monetary policy loosens even further as deposit rates are cut closer to the \(1\%\) .

While inflows have been strong into high- grade credit funds, they have been relatively more muted into high- yield ones over the past three- four years (exhibit 33). This has been a drag on the high- yield market in relative terms, as liquidity metrics have been improving "faster" in high- grade bond trading (exhibit 35 and 36).

In this section, we focus on transaction (bid/offer) costs across the corporate bond market. Our universe spans euro- IG (ERO0 index) and HY (HE00 index) bonds. We also examine transaction costs for the IG sterling market (URO0 index), as well as subordinated debt instruments (in GNEC and COCO index). We present the transaction cost trajectories over the past decade, in absolute basis points terms, but also normalized to the market spread.

As portfolio trading penetration has been more a feature of the high- grade corporate bond market vis- à- vis the high- yield market, transaction costs have not been able to keep up in both worlds to the same extent, thus leaving high- yield bond markets worse off in relative terms (see Exhibit 40), with the high yield bonds lagging the rally down in transaction costs compared to IG bonds (with the current gap at around \(0.25\%\) of quoted Px).

CDS indices and CDS index options remain the "go- to" products in periods of high market volatility. Credit investors gravitate to macro credit instruments to source stronger liquidity characteristics. Higher trade volumes and tighter transaction costs, on top of countercyclical behaviour, are features that make the synthetics macro market the place to source "liquidity" (via CDS indices) and "convexity" (via CDS index options) hedges.
During the Covid- 19 crisis in Q1 2020, but also the market sell- off in early 2022 on the back of rates market and geopolitical risk- driven uncertainty, volumes in the CDS index

space rose materially. Q1 2020 and Q1 2022 CDS index volumes were around \(85\%\) and \(210\%\) higher vs. quarterly averages (up to those points in time), respectively. Similarly, CDS index option trading was up \(66\%\) and \(67\%\) vs. average quarterly trading since 2013, for Q1 2020 and Q1 2022 (up to those points in time), respectively.

Liquidity across macro pockets has also increased materially in 2025, amid higher market volatility both in the downside, but also during the upside. Especially in the options space, trade counts have been only higher during the Covid- 19 crisis- instigated sell- off, while CDS index volumes are only lower compared with the early 2022 market sell- off on the back of the rates market sell- off. Overall, in more macro- driven markets, credit investors have increasingly focused on trading credit index- related products to manage risk and access liquidity. On the flipside, volumes have fallen in periods of low market volatility and a more stable macroeconomic environment.

Credit investors (who can use CDS in their portfolios) tend to prefer to manage part of their directional risk via CDS indices. This is predominantly due to better liquidity (vs. single- name CDS and corporate bonds), which is reflected in much tighter bid/offer spreads. In that form the CDS index can performs as a "liquidity hedge" for corporate bond portfolios.

Exhibit 41: Volumes in the CDS index market increased materially in periods of higher market volatility. When market volatility rises, CDS index volumes increase notably (2011- 2025) Over the past year volumes have increased notably on the back of a need to manage risk in bond books.
Source: DTCC Trading volume nationals in Sbn. Data from 2011 to date

Using the CDS index as a tool to hedge downside risks has been growing in popularity among credit investors, while the bond market liquidity backdrop is becoming more challenging. Therefore, we think fewer bond investors have been required to sell bonds to derisk over the past couple of years Credit investors have been embracing CDS indices as a market risk management tool, to manage their portfolio beta. CDS indices benefit from higher liquidity, in the form of higher traded notionals but also notably tighter bid/offer transaction costs.

The benefit of adding CDS indices to credit portfolios for risk management purposes is significant, in our view. Adding CDS indices to the toolbox allows investors to turn the boat faster and more efficiently amid elevated market volatility - on the upside but also on the downside. A CDS index acts as an effective "liquidity hedge" when added to corporate bond portfolios.

Credit accounts are looking for liquidity and scalability via CDS indices as the cash bond market tends to exhibit less liquidity when volatility rises. We could say that CDS indices nicely complement the cash bond market, as their liquidity is actually countercyclical. We find that liquidity in CDS indices is positively correlated to market volatility. When the market becomes more volatile, on both the upside and downside, credit accounts resort to trading CDS indices to manage risk and betas, increasing volumes traded via the CDS index product.

Market shocks: credit investors resort to trading risk via the CDS index market In exhibit 42 we present the countercyclical relationship between CDS index trading volumes and market volatility. We show the weekly volumes across the CDS index market (beta- adjusted across European indices based on running spread) vs. the 3M fixed maturity implied vol ranges (over a six- week rolling moving average) as a measure of vol- of- vol in the market (we use iTraxx Main volatility data). The higher (lower) the vol- of- vol and thus the shock (irrespective of the direction), the higher (lower) the volumes traded in the CDS index market. When market shocks materialise, credit investors resort to trading risk via the CDS index market.

Countercyclical liquidity should be a key feature for a hedging instrument. When liquidity becomes more challenging in bonds during sharp market moves, it is highly beneficial to use another product as a "liquidity hedge". In simple terms, CDS index market depth improves when credit investors really need it the most.

Exhibit 42: CDS index trading volumes multiply when there is a significant rise in market volatility, providing a trading "safe haven" for credit investors CDS indices exhibit counter- cyclical behaviour vs. market volatility

Source: BofA Global Research; DTCC; CDS index volumes refer to iTraxx Main, XO and Senior Fins (all series) CDS indices, on a weekly basis. We aggregate based on the respective index spread level vs that of iTraxx Main; i.e. beta adjusted. Data from 2013 to date. BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

For years, the ever- increasing impact of the macro backdrop on credit markets has shifted the focus of credit investors to the CDS index from the single- name (SN) CDS market. Highly accommodative monetary policy among central banks across the globe has dampened macro risks and supported risk- taking. As a result, concentration in the SN CDS market has been increasing since 2012.

However, there have been periods where investors have embraced more the "alpha" side of the CDS market. In the aftermath of the Covid- 19 crisis, the market became less concentrated. Amid higher default risks, credit fundamentals mattered more. It was the same story in 2022 and, amid higher funding costs as central banks pushed deep rates
much higher, fundamentals mattered more. This resulted in less concentrated SN CDS trading volumes.

On the flipside, since early 2023, and amid more stable markets, while spreads have started to compress, market concentration has been relatively range- bound in single- name CDS land. At the peak (around mid- 2024), around \(85\%\) of volumes in the European SN CDS space were concentrated among only 50 issuers (of \(\sim 270\) issuers in our sample). Fast forward a year and we see the rise of idiosyncratic risk amid trade wars pushing the market concentration down to around \(78\%\) .

Exhibit 43: More macro- driven markets have made the single- name CDS market less dispersed. % of volumes concentrated in the top 50 names out of \(\sim 270\) SN European entities CDS contracts (dark blue line is the 12- week average)

Over the past decade, the CDS index options market has strengthened as an increasing number of risk managers have looked for convex downside- protection hedges. The reason for this is simple: when investors look to short credit via the CDS index market, most of the time they face a negative carry- and- roll profile that becomes especially painful when markets are grinding tighter.

However, the CDS index options market offers downside hedging at a predetermined cost (paid at the inception of a trade). This gives credit investors a payoff profile, which is what a real hedge should offer: predetermined cost and positive downside convexity (in the case of a put/payer option for instance).

The need for convexity hedges typically intensifies in periods of stress. But we think such demand should be structural and not restricted to these periods alone. When spreads are tight and implied vols are low, the cost to own downside hedges falls notably, presenting a great way to insulate portfolios against downside. This is a theme we have highlighted for a number of years, namely that fragility is a structural phenomenon. Fragility shocks have reoccurred over the past couple of years, highlighting the importance of owning cheap downside convexity hedges.

Investors should keep looking for liquid ways to protect their bond portfolios against sharp and sizeable downside risks, amid challenging bond market liquidity when market stress arises. Note the significant rise in trading of CDS index options during periods of market stress, amid a growing appetite to source tail risk hedges.

In the later parts of 2023 and early 2024, liquidity trends for the option market declined, as market volatility subsided, while a dovish shift from central banks reduced the need for tail hedges. Over the past year or so, though, trade counts have increased notably in the CDS index options market. This was initially due to very tight trading levels across credit markets, with investors increasingly incentivised to own for downside hedges, thus instigating a significant rise in CDS index options trading.

Exhibit 44: Credit index options market has seen strong trading during periods of market stress The Covid-19 sell-off and the 2022 rates market selloff are the periods when the CDS index options market saw the highest trading activity over the past 10 years. Trading activity is rising again amid trade war jitters.

Source: Bloomberg SDR page; Number of unique options trades across five CDS indices (iTraxx Main, XO, Senior Fins, CDX IG and CDX HY). Note the analysis is underestimating the overall market trade counts as it is not capturing trades where a non US counterpart is involved. BoFA GLOBAL RESEARCH

The trade war saga and market jitters over the past couple of months, but also the rebound post the market sell- off, have spurred investors to search for convexity in the form of downside protection (via payer structures), but also to find cheap ways to own upside (via receivers). We note that liquidity metrics (unique trade counts) in the CDS index options market are currently only marginally lower than at the peak of hedging demand during the Covid- 19 crisis.

Macro credit is not only centred around the CDS index market. We also see more reliance on IG and HY market allocation via the ETF market over the past few years to express macro views for credit investors. There has been a big increase in the AUM share of ETFs vs. the entire market, too. Note also that the credit market has been closing the gap – though still notable – on the use of ETFs vs. levels in the equity market.

While ETF market volumes have been steadily increasing over the past few years, investors have been able to diversify across a larger number of ETF offerings. Exhibit 46 highlights that the market concentration has been declining steadily. As a result, a smaller proportion of the ETF market has seen the lion's share of volumes, as trading activity is spread across an increasing pool of credit- focused ETFs. This has been the case for the past two years.

All in all, we think this shows that investors are now able to diversify across different ETF providers/strategies. In our view, that trend coincides with the expansion of portfolio trading and the higher reliance on that "technology" for ETFs to build their assets and accumulate bonds. This allows for more efficient creation of ETFs, implying a lower overall cost.

During Q1 2020, Q1 2022 and the most recent market sell- off, transaction costs increased markedly in both the CDS (index and single- names) and corporate bond markets (Exhibits 47- 50). While both credit instruments' bid/offer (b/o) costs were affected, transaction costs normalised quickly in the CDS index space. We saw a similar reaction during the market weakness of 2022, driven by rates and geopolitics. It was the same story during the most recent sell- off.
